PT J
AU Stevens, P
AF Stevens, Paul
TI Early Medieval Jet-like Jewellery in Ireland: Production, Distribution
   and Consumption
SO MEDIEVAL ARCHAEOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
AB JET-LIKE JEWELLERY, encompassing polished black stone arm-rings, bangles and bracelets, has not been subject to detailed study in Ireland for over 50 years. This paper refocuses attention on the archaeological evidence for the indigenous production of this type of jewellery in early medieval Ireland, with the aims of exploring its distribution and consumption, and its relevance to networks of social control and economic expansion. Using geospatial and stratigraphic interrogation of the archaeological record, and contemporary comparison with recent studies from Scotland, this article demonstrates a hitherto unrecognised level of complexity and diversity in the handling of this ubiquitous luxury item. Regional specialised production centres and separate distribution centres are identified, and while a focus on indigenous sources is apparent, this is not exclusive. Degrees of cooperation and exclusivity are suggested for ecclesiastical and secular social hierarchies.
C1 [Stevens, Paul] Univ Coll Dublin, Sch Archaeol, Dublin 4, Ireland.
C3 University College Dublin
RP Stevens, P (corresponding author), Univ Coll Dublin, Sch Archaeol, Dublin 4, Ireland.
EM paul.stevens@ucdconnect.ie
OI Stevens, Paul/0000-0002-6884-0159
FU Irish Research Council, Government of Ireland Postgraduate Scholarship
   Scheme
FX Thanks to Aidan O'Sullivan for the helpful comments on drafts of this
   text and for ongoing mentorship, help and guidance over the past four
   and a half years. Thanks to Dr Ros O Maolduin for assistance with
   fieldwork, Heather A King, Jackie McDowell, Dr Stephen Davis and Con
   Manning for access to unpublished archival material and also to the
   staff of the Antiquities Division, National Museum of Ireland for access
   to the museum archives. Work for this article forms part of doctoral
   research at UCD School of Archaeology on the role of the church in the
   expansion of the early Irish economy, ad 400-1100, supervised by
   Professor Aidan O'Sullivan. The research was fully funded by the Irish
   Research Council, Government of Ireland Postgraduate Scholarship Scheme
   (2013-2017). Any omissions, errors and exclusions are exclusively the
   fault of the author.

PT J
AU Skre, D
AF Skre, Dagfinn
TI Monetary Practices in Early Medieval Western Scandinavia (5th-10th
   Centuries AD)
SO MEDIEVAL ARCHAEOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
ID MONEY ECONOMY; PERSPECTIVE; HISTORY
AB A SOCIAL APPROACH TO MONETISATION shifts the attention from the classic money media-gold and silver-to the dissemination of two social practices: valuing and paying. When these two monetary practices first became widespread in western Scandinavia during the gold rich migration period (in the 5th to 6th centuries AD), they were not introduced in the sphere of trade, but instead were features of traditional or customary payments, such as weregeld (atonements for murder or offences against the person) or marriage dowries. By the Viking Age, in the late 8th to 10th centuries AD, despite flourishing commodity production, precious metals were used as payment in trade solely in towns. Even in towns, this commercial use seems to have been adopted late, and was employed only occasionally. This paper reviews the changing approaches to money and monetisation, and draws attention to the potential for regarding monetisation as the spread of a set of social practices.
C1 [Skre, Dagfinn] Univ Oslo, Museum Cultural Hist, POB 6762 St Olavs Plass, NO-0130 Oslo, Norway.
C3 University of Oslo
RP Skre, D (corresponding author), Univ Oslo, Museum Cultural Hist, POB 6762 St Olavs Plass, NO-0130 Oslo, Norway.
EM dagfinn.skre@khm.uio.no
OI Skre, Dagfinn/0000-0003-4869-0189
FU Avaldsnes Royal Manor Project - Avaldsnes Municipality; Ministry of
   Education and Research
FX This paper was written under the auspices of the Avaldsnes Royal Manor
   Project < https://www.khm.uio.no/english/research/projects/avaldsnes/>
   funded by Avaldsnes Municipality and the Ministry of Education and
   Research. Avaldsnes (Old Norse Ogvaldsnes) is located in Rogaland
   County, which in the 4th-6th centuries AD was the western Scandinavian
   region richest in gold.

PT J
AU Thomas, G
   Pluskowski, A
   Gilchrist, R
   Ruiz, GGC
   Andrén, A
   Augenti, A
   Astill, G
   Staecker, J
   Valk, H
AF Thomas, Gabor
   Pluskowski, Aleks
   Gilchrist, Roberta
   Garcia-Contreras Ruiz, Guillermo
   Andren, Anders
   Augenti, Andrea
   Astill, Grenville
   Staecker, Jorn
   Valk, Heiki
TI Religious Transformations in the Middle Ages: Towards a New
   Archaeological Agenda
SO MEDIEVAL ARCHAEOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
ID SYNCRETISM; HYBRIDITY; LYMINGE; MINSTER; TIME
AB UNDERSTANDING RELIGIOUS CHANGE between the collapse of the Roman Empire and the Reformation forms one of the cornerstones of medieval archaeology, but has been riven by period, denominational, and geographical divisions. This paper lays the groundwork for a fundamental rethink of archaeological approaches to medieval religions, by adopting an holistic framework that places Christian, pagan, Islamic and Jewish case studies of religious transformation in a long-term, cross-cultural perspective. Focused around the analytical themes of 'hybridity and resilience' and 'tempo and trajectories', our approach shifts attention away from the singularities of national narratives of religious conversion, towards a deeper understanding of how religious beliefs, practices and identity were renegotiated by medieval people in their daily lives.
C1 [Thomas, Gabor; Astill, Grenville] Univ Reading, Dept Archaeol, Reading RG6 6AB, Berks, England.
   [Garcia-Contreras Ruiz, Guillermo] Univ Granada, Fac Filosofia & Letras, Area Hist Medieval, Campus Cartuja S-N, E-18071 Granada, Spain.

   [Valk, Heiki] Univ Tartu, Dept Archaeol, Tartu, Estonia.

PT J
AU Everson, P
   Stocker, D
AF Everson, Paul
   Stocker, David
TI 'The Cros in the Markitte Stede'. The Louth Cross, its Monastery and its
   Town370
SO MEDIEVAL ARCHAEOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
AB A RECENT DISCOVERY of pieces from a major pre-Conquest cross at Louth in east Lincolnshire has prompted not just a description and assessment of the stone sculpture, but exploration of the evolution of the early monastery and town itself. It is suggested that the monument was erected as an emblematic market cross, which marked the bishop of Lindsey's mid-10th-century promotion of a market and market town at Louth, as part of his effort to re-establish himself in the region after the Viking land-taking and its English reconquest. Our analysis has wider significance than the art history of the sculpture alone, and demonstrates the potential of the large body of early stone sculpture now made more accessible through the publication of corpora in Britain.
C1 [Everson, Paul] 6 Monks Lane, Nantwich CW5 5DN, Cheshire, England.
   [Stocker, David] Univ Leeds, Inst Medieval Studies, Leeds LS2 9JT, W Yorkshire, England.
C3 University of Leeds
RP Everson, P (corresponding author), 6 Monks Lane, Nantwich CW5 5DN, Cheshire, England.
EM everson6@btinternet.com; imsds@leeds.ac.uk

PT J
AU Dempsey, K
AF Dempsey, Karen
TI Understanding 'Hall-Houses': Debating Seigneurial Buildings in Ireland
   in the 13th Century
SO MEDIEVAL ARCHAEOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
AB THE SEIGNURIAL HALL and chamber have been assumed, in both Britain and Ireland, to be typically located in the only building to generally survive on medieval residential sites. In England this idea has seen some revision, but in Ireland there has been little recent scholarship on medieval residential spaces. As a consequence, the term 'hall-house' is still used by Irish scholars as a label for some two-storey, 13th-century buildings, providing both a description and interpretation. The inference is that these buildings acted as both halls and elite residences at the same time during the High to Late Middle Ages. This contradicts what we know of the complex social codes of the time. Drawing on new empirical research, this article challenges the 'hall-house' classification, and explores different ways in which the spaces of these Irish medieval buildings can be better understood.
C1 [Dempsey, Karen] Univ Reading, Dept Archaeol Geog & Environm Sci, Reading, Berks, England.
C3 University of Reading
RP Dempsey, K (corresponding author), Univ Reading, Dept Archaeol Geog & Environm Sci, Reading, Berks, England.
EM k.dempsey@reading.ac.uk
OI Dempsey, Karen/0000-0001-9025-3535
FU Irish Research Council
FX This research was conducted as part of a PhD project completed at
   University College Dublin, School of Archaeology, and funded by the
   Irish Research Council. The article has benefitted from the expertise
   and input of Professor Tadhg O'Keeffe, Dr Rob Sands, Conor McDermott and
   Dr Neil Carlin. Thanks to Dr Seamus O Murchu for his assistance in map
   making. I would like to thank the landowners who gave permission for
   access for the surveys.

PT J
AU Christie, N
   Naylor, J
   Vitali, T

AF Christie, Neil
   Naylor, John
   Vitali, Tiziana
   Gleeson, Patrick
   Carragain, Tomas O.
TI Medieval Britain and Ireland in 2016
SO MEDIEVAL ARCHAEOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
AB This section of the journal comprises two core sets of reports linked to work in 2016: finds and analyses relating to the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS) and site-specific discoveries and reports in medieval Britain and Ireland (MB&I), with a selection of highlighted projects. For the PAS report, reviews on coin and non-coin finds and on specific research angles are presented. For MB&I, the Society is most grateful to all contributors (of field units, museums, universities, developers, specialist groups and individuals) who have provided reports on finds, excavations, field-surveys and building analyses for 2016. For MB&I, see below for the format and content of the Fieldwork Highlights section and for contact details of the compilers. Annual Specialist Groups Reports appear in the Society's Newsletter.

PT J
AU Sorensen, TF
AF Sorensen, Tim Flohr
TI The Two Cultures and a World Apart: Archaeology and Science at a New
   Crossroads
SO NORWEGIAN ARCHAEOLOGICAL REVIEW
LA English
DT Article
ID BRONZE-AGE ARTIFACTS; MOVING METALS
AB Within the past decade or so, archaeology has increasingly utilised and contributed to major advances in scientific methods when exploring the past. This progress is frequently celebrated as a quantum leap in the possibilities for understanding the archaeological record, opening up hitherto inaccessible dimensions of the past. This article represents a critique of the current consumption of science in archaeology, arguing that the discipline's grounding in the humanities is at stake, and that the notion of 'interdisciplinarity' is becoming distorted with the increasing fetishisation of 'data', 'facts' and quantitative methods. It is argued that if archaeology is to break free of its self-induced inferiority to and dependence on science, it must revitalise its methodology for asking questions pertinent to the humanities.
C1 [Sorensen, Tim Flohr] Univ Copenhagen, Saxo Inst, Copenhagen, Denmark.
C3 University of Copenhagen
RP Sorensen, TF (corresponding author), Univ Copenhagen, Saxo Inst, Copenhagen, Denmark.

PT J
AU Hacigüzeller, P
AF Haciguzeller, Piraye
TI Archaeological (Digital) Maps as Performances: Towards Alternative
   Mappings
SO NORWEGIAN ARCHAEOLOGICAL REVIEW
LA English
DT Article
ID INDIGENOUS PEOPLE; CARTOGRAPHY; TERRITORY; COMMUNITY; REPRESENTATION;
   DONT; ARTS
AB In this article, a case is made to reconceptualise archaeological cartography from a performative perspective. Through such a discussion the aim is not only to render archaeology an active part in related multidisciplinary discussions within the field of critical mapping but also to open up possibilities for alternative mapping practices in the discipline. While pursuing this reconceptualisation, I first discuss how to rethink maps as performances. Subsequently, I present understanding archaeological maps as performances as a way to create alternatives to representational modes of thinking. Finally, I stress the timeliness of reconceptualising maps as performances in digital age.
C1 [Haciguzeller, Piraye] Univ Ghent, Dept Archaeol, Ghent, Belgium.
   [Haciguzeller, Piraye] Univ Ghent, Ghent Ctr Digital Humanities, Ghent, Belgium.
C3 Ghent University; Ghent University

SO JOURNAL OF ROMAN ARCHAEOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
FU Soprintendenza Archeologica di Napoli e Pompei; Semple Fund of the
   Department of Classics at the University of Cincinnati; Loeb Classical
   Library Foundation; National Geographic Society; National Endowment for

FX The work has been possible thanks to the generous support of the
   Soprintendenza Archeologica di Napoli e Pompei and the Beni Culturali,
   and especially to our friends and colleagues Pier Giovanni Guzzo and
   Antonio d'Ambrosio of the former administration, more recently Teresa
   Cinquantaquattro, Antonio Varone and Grete Stefani, and lately Massimo
   Osanna. Special thanks go to The Oplontis Project, The Center for the
   Study of Ancient Italy, and the Department of Art and Art History at the
   University of Texas at Austin, and in particular to John Clarke,
   Penelope Davies, Michael Thomas and Rabun Taylor, for their invaluable
   support and feedback. Kevin Dicus and Allison Emmerson assisted in the
   sequencing of the stratified deposits of the Porta Stabia trenches. The
   Semple Fund of the Department of Classics at the University of
   Cincinnati, where the project is based, has generously funded the
   research, with additional and most generous support from the Loeb
   Classical Library Foundation, the National Geographic Society and, not
   least, the National Endowment for the Humanities. As a project that is
   also under the aegis of the American Academy in Rome, we are grateful to
   the Academy for its support, guidance and resources. The paper builds on
   the tireless efforts of all those involved in the "Pompeii
   Archaeological Research Project: Porta Stabia"; for more on the project,
   including a more complete bibliography, see
   http://classics.uc.edu/pompeii/
